generic.text: The first Chinese trader to write about Southeast Asia.  He was born around 1311 in Nanchang, known in earlier times as Hongzhou, which was a prosperous port in Jiangxi Province during the Song Dynasty. The town is not far from Jingdezhen, the great centre of porcelain production. Nanchang may have been a centre of porcelain trade in the Yuan period. In 1349, Wang’s composition Dao yi zhi lue (“Description of the Barbarians of the Isles”) was incorporated into a local gazetteer, Qingyuan xuzhi, "A Continuation of the History and Topography of Quanzhou", by Wu Jian. In a postscript to his book, Wang wrote: “I ‘attached’ to a boat when I was young to go for sea-travel”. This sentiment seems to describe a trader who booked space on a ship for himself and his goods. Wang made two voyages, one from 1330 to 1334, and the other from 1337 to 1339. It is also believed that he lived in Quanzhou, Fujian Province, for some time.

results.text: ? 1998 by National University of Singapore From Quanzhou to the Sulu Zone and Beyond: Questions Related to the Early Fourteenth Century University of Munich Introduction Ships sailing from Fujian to Southeast Asia could choose between two different sea routes. The first route followed the China coast to central Guangdong; it then led to Hainan, the Champa coast and Pulau Condore, an island near the southern tip of Vietnam. From there it continued in three directions: to Siam, to northwestern Borneo and to the Malayan east coast. Going south to the Malayan east coast was the most direct way to Trengganu, Pahang, Pulau Tioman, Johore and modern Singapore whence it was possible to sail into the Indian Ocean or to cross over to Sumatra, Bangka Island and Java. The second trunk route connecting Fujian to Southeast Asia also consisted of several segments. The first was the passage from the China coast to southwestern Taiwan and northwestern Luzon. From there ships could proceed to Mindoro and the Calamian group. Having cut through Mindoro Strait, they usually went to Palawan, following the coast of this island in a southwesterly direction until they reached Balabac Strait and the Kota Kinabalu coast of Sabah. The next section of the route ran along the coast of northern Borneo to Cape Datu where it merged with the branch route from southern Vietnam. From northwestern Borneo ships would either sail to Johore or continue southbound to Pontianak, Karimata Island, Billiton Island, eastern Sumatra or northern Java. Beyond Mindoro and the Calamian group this second route had many additional branches, leading to various places in the central and southern Philippines. Another major branch connected Mindoro to western Mindanao and Jolo on the Sulu Islands. The Sulu Islands, which could also be reached from the west by way of Palawan and Balabac Strait, controlled the northern exit of the Celebes Sea. From the Celebes Sea, ships either entered Makassar Strait, going to southern Sulawesi and eastern Java, or proceeded to the Sangihe group and then to the Moluccas. Beyond the Moluccas navigation was rather complicated. The Gulf of Tomini could be entered from these islands by taking a westerly course, but this side route was not very important. Sailing from Tidore, Ternate and other Moluccan islands through the Ceram Sea to Ambon was more common because much trade could be done in these regions. From Ambon, ships either sailed to the Banda Islands or to Timor and other places in the Lesser Sunda group, or they went directly to Madura and Java. The Banda Islands and Timor constituted the southeastern terminal points of many shipping lines to eastern Indonesia.1 (See map.) 1 These sea routes are described in full in Ming sources but they were of course known much earlier to navigators of different countries. For the Ming period, see especially J. V. Mills, "Chinese Navigators in Insulinde about A.D. 1500", Archipel 18 (1979): 69-93. Eastern Indonesia could of course also be reached by way of the Java Sea ? from Madura, Johore, eastern Sumatra, and so on. But this route is not of primary concern to the present notes. Here, the main focus will be on the eastern link, that is, on the route from Fujian down to the Sulu zone and to a certain extent also on the route from there to eastern Indonesia. The period chiefly dealt with in these notes is the Yuan period. In brief, it is intended to construct a hypothetical picture of why and how this eastern route became an important artery of trade in the times of Wang Dayuan and other fourteenth-century travellers. To achieve this, various arguments will be assembled. Many of these have been considered in previous studies, but to my knowledge they have never been pieced together to form one "coherent image".2 I shall begin the discussion by reviewing Yuan concepts of the Asian seas and the segmentation of these seas into geographical zones. There will then follow some remarks on the China end of the eastern route and a chronologically arranged survey intended to compare its role in the Yuan period to its role under the Song and early Ming. An important facet frequently overlooked ? trade across the South China Sea between the Philippines and continental Southeast Asia ? the possible role of Tanjongpura, religious and other dimensions will also be highlighted. The final section, which examines commodity flows, is mainly based on Wang Dayuan's Daoyi zhiliie (hereafter DYZL) as, indeed, many other parts of these notes are as well. Southeast Asia's Seas in Yuan Concepts of Space It is clear that Chinese sailors of the Yuan period knew the direct access route to eastern Indonesia described above, but the way in which they segmented Southeast Asia into different "oceanic zones" or "macro regions" is another matter. Unfortunately, there are only two sources which convey something like a spacial concept of these regions. The first work is the Dade Nanhai zhi (dated 1304). This book, now only available as a fragment, contains a long list of geographical names grouped under different headings. What is of interest here, is that these headings include the names Xiao Xiyang, Xiao Dongyang and Da Dongyang, respectively "Small Western Ocean", "Small Eastern Ocean" and "Big Eastern Ocean". From the place names associated with each of these entitites, it becomes clear that the first ocean comprised the Gulf of Siam and the area stretching from eastern Sumatra via Aceh to Sri Lanka; the second ocean was roughly identical with 2One of the more recent monographs on Yuan maritime trade is Yu Changsen, Yuandai haiwai maoyi (Xi'an: Xibei daxue chubanshe, 1994). At the southeastern rim of this third ocean, the Da Dongyang, lay Timor and the Banda group. Its northern and northeastern rim overlapped with the Xiao Dongyang in the Sarawak and Sabah area. The above segmen tation suggests that the "eastern" sea route examined here fell into the terrain of the two eastern oceans; it clearly had nothing to do with the Xiao Xiyang.3 The second source with an underlying spatial segmentation is the DYZL (prefaces 1349/50). This book is divided into one hundred segments. Segments 1 to 99 describe places which the author, Wang Dayuan, claims to have seen himself. The last segment contains brief notes on places known to him through the accounts of others. The two middle segments of the book ? chapters 49 and 50 ? deal with Singapore Strait (Longyamen) and Pulau Condore (Kunlun). Pulau Condore, says the text, was on the way to the Xiyang, the "Western Ocean"; Singapore Strait constituted the passage between this ocean and the eastern world. The eastern world, the Dongyang, was dominated by Majapahit, as we know from the Java chapter of the same source. Thus, in a symbolic way, the two middle segments of Wang's account fall together with the dividing line between two major oceans, the Dongyang and the Xiyang.4 Wang Dayuan's concept of the Xiyang roughly corresponded to the area of the Indian Ocean; the Dongyang comprised the seas to the east of Singapore Strait, that is, nearly all of Southeast Asia. Some other oceans and seas are mentioned in the DYZL as well, but for the eastern route to Indonesia only one additional name is of relevance ? the Xiao Dongyang. It can be found in chapter 27, which deals with a place called Jianshan, probably a location on Palawan. The reader is not told how far the Xiao Dongyang extended to the east and south, nor whether this ocean was seen as a separate geographical entity or as part of the Dongyang. But there seems to be a "formal counterpart" to the Xiao Dongyang in chapter 72 (note: 99 chapters minus 72 gives 27); this is the Dalang Ocean, or the Gulf of Mannar between Sri Lanka and South India. This can also be said of some Song sources and early Ming works. In general however, the twofold partition of the Asian seas into an Eastern and a Western Ocean was well-established under the Yuan and Ming and many authors made use of it, although the geographical implications were modified in later periods, for example by Zhang Xie.6 What is special about Yuan concepts of space is the relative weight they assign to the eastern seas ? these are juxtaposed to the Western Ocean on an equal basis. By contrast, early Ming sources on Southeast Asia and the Indian Ocean are "biased" towards the Western Ocean; in the view of these works the Western Ocean and the most direct route to it, the one closely following the Chinese and Vietnamese coasts, were definitely more important than the world beyond Borneo and Java. Similarly, no early- or mid-Ming work presents as clear a concept of the delimitations of the eastern seas as the Nanhai zhi. This difference in the perception of space reflects different political and economic constellations, as we shall see below. The Institutional Side of Yuan Trade at the China End Technically all Chinese imports from maritime Asia had to go through the so-called Maritime Supervisorates, or shibosi. The most important supervisorate was the one in Quanzhou. Ships arriving with foreign goods were inspected by the officers of these supervisorates and had to pay duties. Licenses were issued to vessels sailing abroad. This system was modified from time to time, but by and large it was the same under the Yuan as it had been under the Song. Unlike the late Ming, the Yuan made no formal distinction between ships sailing to Eastern Ocean and ships going to Western Ocean destinations. One major adjustment occurred towards the end of Mongol rule when many commodities originally assigned to the coarse category were put in the fine category to increase tax revenues.8 The results of these alterations are not known. Practically, however, such a distinction cannot be made: first, adequate quantitative material does not exist; second, most items were produced and sold in more than one place, which makes it impossible to identify them with only one route or sector; and finally, for some commodities it is not known whether they were put in the coarse or fine grade category. It is possible, therefore, that commodities collected along this route mostly went into Fujian and not into central Guangdong or Zhejiang. If so, then most taxes collected on imports from eastern Indonesia, Borneo and the Philippines were generated in Quanzhou, and products of the eastern areas probably held a higher share on the Quanzhou market than on other Chinese markets. The economic importance of the route through the eastern seas was thus associated with Fujian. The Eastern Route in the Chronological Context: Song to Early Ming Song accounts refer to some islands in eastern Indonesia but contain no descriptions of these places and say nothing about China's relations with that area. There is some news on Borneo and the Philippines in Song works, especially in the Zhufan zhi (1225), and we also know of official contacts between China and Butuan (on Mindanao) under the northern Song, yet few if any Chinese ships appear to have sailed beyond Mindanao and the Sulu Islands into the Celebes Sea at that time. Song China, there can be no doubt, was mostly looking towards the ports and countries along the western route. Accordingly, official sources list dozens of tribute embassies arriving from Java, Srivijaya and continental Southeast Asia. Conditions in Southeast Asia were fairly stable, and Srivijaya acted as the major bridge between the Far East and the Indian Ocean world. Most of China's import revenues were drawn from trade along the western route, with Guangzhou being the leading port-of-call at the China end. It was only in the second half of the Song period that Quanzhou, one of its rivals, became more intensively involved in trade along the eastern route, but, as indicated, this trade rarely went beyond the Sulu chain.10 Under the Yuan this picture changed. Tribute embassies to China continued to arrive from western Indonesia, but southeastern Sumatra came under temporary pressure now, mainly from Siam and Java. Java, in particular, expanded its influence over some of its neighbours. The Yuan, unwilling to accept this, warned Siam and sent a major fleet against Java (1292). Although the campaign failed to attain all its objectives, Mongol intervention on Java must have disturbed commercial shipping in the area. Champa was also hurt by military intervention from outside, first through a Mongol invasion, then through the temporary presence of the Yuan fleet which passed the Vietnam coast on its way to Java, and finally through Vietnamese attacks. The Annan zhiliie, probably from the 1330s, refers to Champa as an important stopover for southbound trade from China, but it is possible that there were temporary setbacks along the Champa coast due to these disturbances.11 In sum, conditions along the western trunk route from Guangzhou via Vietnam to Southeast Asia were not as stable as in the Song period. This may have worked to the disadvantage of Guangzhou and to the advantage of Fujian and the eastern route to the Philippines and the Spice Islands which became important in Yuan days. As indicated above, the principal Yuan work with data on the Philippines and eastern Indonesia is the DYZL. Its author, Wang Dayuan, was linked to Quanzhou and is thought of having travelled to Southeast Asia, India, the Arabian peninsula and even Africa. These voyages can be dated to the 1330s. The descriptions collected in his book probably mostly refer to the same period.12 Broadly speaking, he was a contemporary of Ibn Battuta who sailed in the other direction ? from North Africa to the Far East. It is still difficult to say how many of the 99 places Wang claims to have seen were really visited by him, but in many cases he is the earliest reference to a particular island, an ethnographical detail, or the trade in a specific commodity. Presumably he also travelled to some islands in the Sulu zone and eastern Indonesia. His account is the first to furnish detailed information on the Sulu group, the Moluccas, the Banda Islands, Timor and other eastern Indonesian places. No Arabic work nor any other Chinese source, from the earliest times down to the days of the great Ming expeditions under Zheng He, carries comparable news on these regions. Many Muslim traders residing in that port probably retreated to Southeast Asia.14 Shortly thereafter, the Hongwu emperor prohibited private Chinese sea trade. At the same time, Java became strong again. Soon, Majapahit claimed nominal suzerainty over Borneo and the Sulu Islands. Few Ming ships, therefore, sailed through the Celebes Sea. Now, Brunei and the Sulu Islands competed for China's nominal protection, sending several high-ranking embassies to the court of Yongle, but private contacts between China and the outside world remained forbidden and official Chinese trade was mainly directed to Champa, Siam, western Indonesia, Malacca and the Indian Ocean. Indirectly, this state of affairs is reflected in both official and private writings of this period. Chinese participation in trade along this route was probably also highest in the Mongol period. At the China end this trade focused on Quanzhou. We still have to look at Butuan and briefly return to the Song period once again. The Song huiyao states that Butuan was "under" Champa, and Zhao Rugua lists another place, Bosilan, as a "dependency" of Cambodia. Some scholars have identified Bosilan with Basilan, an island between Jolo and Zamboanga on Mindanao. If this identification is correct, then there may have been some kind of nominal subordination of two Philippine polities under two countries of the Southeast Asian mainland.19 But then, what was the role of Mindoro in this curious constellation? Mindoro was almost halfway between Butuan and Champa. Did it also "depend" on Champa? Nothing points to a continuation of a nominal relationship between continental Southeast Asia and the Philippines in Yuan times. Edwards McKinnon, "A Note on Recent Ceramic Finds at Muara Kaman, Kabupaten Kutei, Kalimantan Commodities Traded along the Eastern Route So far, not too much has been said about the Celebes Sea and the areas farther to the south. One way of looking at Quanzhou's role in trade to eastern Indonesia ? via the Sulu zone ? is to examine Wang Dayuan's references to individual commodity flows. The DYZL, as was said above, contains brief chapters on Mindoro, the Sulu Islands, Borneo or Brunei, the Moluccas, the Banda Islands and Timor. To these we may add a segment on the so-called "Three Islands", possibly Calamian, Palawan and Busuanga (?). Some additional names can also be related to places in the eastern seas: Malilu was thought to stand for the Polillo group on the east side of Luzon or, which is more likely, for Manila Bay; Jianshan could be the Kinabalu area in Sabah but other places were also suggested in the literature; Xialaiwu was equated with the Klabat area on northeastern Sulawesi, others thought it represented the Karimunjawa group off northern Java.33 In all cases Wang Dayuan lists various things produced by or imported to these places. We shall look at the imports first. Ceramic articles, articles made of copper or iron, and textiles are the most frequently mentioned import items. References to ceramics and metals occur in various other chapters and indeed are so common that no precise conclusions can be drawn with respect to the question of trade routes.34 Textiles mentioned in connection with the Philippines and other eastern places include coloured satin, thin red silks, and damask; presumably these were all exported from Quanzhou, though they were not necessarily produced in Fujian. Other textile products listed by Wang Dayuan are ordinary cottons (sibu), coloured cottons and printed cottons. The first two may have come from South India either by way of the route around northern Borneo or through the Java Sea; the second probably originated from some Southeast Asian port. All varieties are mentioned in other segments as well, but again it is difficult to derive any conclusions.35 Other than the above items a number of fabrics are mentioned in the DYZL which are named according to their place of origin. Hainan cottons (Zhancheng bu and Hainan bu). Interestingly, Champa cottons also appear in the descriptions of some areas along the Malayan east coast, in the chapter on Dudu'an (probably on northwestern Borneo), and in the Timor chapter. Hainan cloth is mentioned in connection with Suluoge (Srokan?), again with Dudu'an, and with Puben, a name variously identified with places on eastern Java, Madura, Bali, or southern Borneo.36 The distribution of these two items suggests that they were chiefly transported from Hainan and Champa along the coastal western route to the area of Siam and Malaysia and then taken to the Java Sea. Clearly, if Xialaiwu was on northeastern Sulawesi, as Su Jiqing suggested, then direct shipments around Sabah through the Celebes Sea are possible as well, but in that case one would expect at least one or two references to these commodities in the segments on Brunei, the Sulu Islands, or other Philippine sites. The absence of such references, it seems to me, may just be another indirect element in support of the above hypothesis that links between Champa, Hainan and the Philippines were no longer important in Yuan days. All other commodities sold to eastern Indonesian and Philippine places are rather unspecific. Therefore, we shall look at Southeast Asian exports now, and the possible implications of their transportation to Yuan China. Again, a number of commodities can be excluded from the discussion almost instantly because they are mentioned too frequently and tell us little about the trade routes. This includes tortoise-shell, cotton (mumian, mumianhua, mumianbu) and beeswax. All three items appear in connection with various places in continental Southeast Asia, western and eastern Indonesia, the Philippines and Borneo.37 The case is somewhat different with pearls, cloves, nutmeg, camphor and sandalwood. We shall deal with these, one by one. Pearls were essentially produced in the Persian Gulf, in the Gulf of Mannar, and near the Sulu Islands. Wang Dayuan mentions the last two as production sites. He briefly summarizes the fishing techniques in his chapter on Disan'gang (most likely Punnaikayal) ? this information was probably taken from earlier sources ? and he furnishes some details on the appearance of the pearls found near the Sulu Islands in the segment on this place. He also indicates that Sulu pearls were different from the ones gathered in the Gulf of Mannar and says that they were highly appreciated by the Chinese. There is no other explicit reference to Sulu pearls in Wang Dayuan's account, nor in any other source of the Yuan period. Yuan sources only speak of domestically-produced pearls and imported 36Chen Jiarong, Xie Fang and Lu Junling, Gudai Nanhai, p. 803 (on Puben). Note that Zhao Rugua, Zhou Qufei and others already refer to Hainan and Champa export fabrics. See, for example, Hirth and Rockhill, Chao Ju-kua, pp. 48, 183, 219-20, and Netolitzky, Das Ling-wai tai-ta, pp. 110-11. For references to Champa and Hainan cottons in DYZL, see pp. 93, 99, 102, 123, 173, 199, 209, 227. On cotton and related products see also, for example, Pelliot, Notes on Marco Polo. Ouvrage posthume, 3 vols. (Paris: Imprimerie Nationale, Librairie Adrien-Maisonneuve, 1959-73). 370n tortoise-shell, see Roderich Ptak, "China and the Trade in Tortoise-shell (Sung to Ming Periods)", in Ptak and Rothermund (eds.), Emporia, Commodities and Entrepreneurs, pp. 195-229; on cotton, Pelliot, Notes on Marco Polo. For a general view of Song imports and commodities traded in Song times, see Paul Wheatley, "Geographical Notes on Some Commodities Involved in Sung Maritime Trade", Journal of the Malayan Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society 32,2 (1959): 5-140. See also the many references in Isaac H. Burkill, A Dictionary of the Economic Products of the Malay Peninsula, with Contributions by William Birtwistle et al, 2 vols. (London and Oxford: On behalf of the Governments of the Straits Settlements and Federated Malay States, At the University Press, 1935), and other handbooks. pearls available in Guangzhou without specifying their origin.38 It is only in early Ming works that more references appear concerning Sulu pearls being brought to China. It thus seems that China's imports of these pearls ? through direct traffic between Fujian and the Sulu zone ? began under the Yuan. The picture we can obtain for the Song period is different. Zhao Rugua lists pearls as a "product" of Mindoro but does not say anything about their possible export nor their place of origin ? perhaps they were obtained from the Sulu area. He also refers to pearls in Brunei or Borneo but again adds nothing further. More important still, he indicates that pearls from the Dashi area (obviously the Persian Gulf) were the best, and more "brilliant" than the ones obtained from domestic sources.39 Other Song works refer to several Srivijayan tribute embassies bringing pearls to China. Java, Tubo (not identified), Tongking, Chola and Wu Yue in Fujian are also listed once or twice in connection with this trade, but in the case of the many Champa embassies to Song China, pearls are not mentioned at all.40 Several hypothetical observations may be derived from all this: first, Song China was exclusively or almost exclusively supplied with pearls from the Indian Ocean and the Gulf ? unless Sulu pearls were brought south, to Srivijaya, and then sent north, which seems rather unlikely; second, Sulu pearls had no significance in trade from Mindoro and Borneo to Champa at that time because there were no Champa reexports to China, or, alternatively, because all Sulu pearls shipped to Champa stayed in that place. The trade in cloves gives a different picture. The only known production site for this spice was the Moluccan Islands. From there cloves flowed via Java and Sumatra to Indian Ocean destinations, the Levant, and Europe. There is ample evidence of this trade in Arabic, Chinese and other works. Demand in China was probably low compared to demand for other spices or demand for cloves in India and the Near East, but small quantities of cloves arrived in China under the Song, Yuan and Ming, as I have shown elsewhere.41 In Song times, these imports were mainly channelled through Champa. Occasionally, cloves were also offered by Srivijaya, Java and Butuan and by merchants from Chola and Persia (Dashi) who probably picked them up on the way through Indonesia. There were thus two routes for Song imports of cloves: from the Moluccas to the Java Sea and from there to Guangzhou, directly or via Champa; and from the Moluccas to the Sulu zone, especially to Butuan, and from there either directly to China, or to Champa and then to China. The only medieval production site of nutmeg was the Banda Islands. Trade in nutmeg, however, is less easy to trace. The full Chinese term for nutmeg is roudoukou, but Song sources often refer to doukou which may also mean cardamom (usually baidoukou). In all, there are fewer references to Song imports of these two commodities than to imports 38For the Gulf of Mannar and Punnaikayal, see DYZL, pp. 287-88; Ptak, "Yuan and Early Ming Notices on the Kayal Area", pp. 138 note 3, 146-47. For domestic Chinese pearls, see, for example, Chen Dazhen, Nanhai zhi, pp. 26, 28, 38. 39Hirth and Rockhill, Chau Ju-kua, especially pp. 157, 160, 229. 40Based on table in Lin Tianwei, Songdai xiangyao maoyi, table, with list of imports, pp. 174? 215. 41Ptak, "China and the Trade in Cloves", pp. 6-8. Much has been written on cloves. One of the most recent works is Luis Filipe F. R. Thomaz, "Especiar?as do velho e do novo mundo (Notas hist?rico-filol?gicas)", in an offprint of the Arquivos do Centro Cultural Calouste Gulbenkian 34 (1995): 267-75. Thomaz also examines some other commodities discussed in the present study. of cloves. Srivijaya can be identified very clearly as an occasional supplier of nutmeg, but in the case of Champa's tribute embassies the ambiguous term doukou is used, and since Indochina was known as a producer of cardamom it is likely that this term did not refer to nutmeg. It may be added that there are no references to Song imports of nutmeg via Butuan or Borneo. This could be taken to imply that Banda's nutmeg almost exclusively went westward and that, if Champa really reexported nutmeg to China (which is unlikely, as we have seen), these were perhaps received through Champa's connection to Java, or Srivijaya.42 In the Yuan period the above scenario underwent a major change. There is little to suggest that cloves were still sent via Indonesia and Champa to China. Instead, Wang Dayuan says that Chinese merchants themselves sailed to the Moluccas and picked up cloves there. Much later, Antonio Galv?o says, Chinese traders "were the first to buy cloves wholesale in these islands", adding that they always came by way of northern Borneo. In all likelihood this statement describes the situation under the Yuan. It may be assumed, therefore, that Fujianese junks regularly sailed beyond the Sulu zone into the Celebes Sea and beyond.43 But written sources do not indicate whether Yuan vessels also became involved as carriers in the nutmeg trade. Indeed, Wang Dayuan says nothing about this commodity except for the fact that it was produced on the Banda Islands. Nutmeg, so it seems, had a small market in China both in Song and Yuan days.44 Whether this excludes active Chinese participation in trade on the route from the Moluccas to Ceram and the Banda group is of course impossible to determine. The next commodity, camphor, was produced in the Barus area of western Sumatra and on Borneo. The Far East also produced a substance known by this name but its chemical composition was different and it was never valued as highly as imported camphor. Song sources list foreign camphor as an import from Srivijaya and Champa. There are also references to imports from Butuan and occasional shipments by merchants from Persia, Chola and Cengtan (on the Arabian Peninsula?). It is obvious that Butuan and Champa received their camphor from Borneo while the other imports originally came from the Barus area. Wang Dayuan refers to camphor products in his chapters on Champa, Trengganu, Samudra, Xialaiwu, Danmaling (Ligor?), Brunei, Pulau Rondo (Longxianxu), Dudu'an, Srivijaya and Suluoge. Camphor, it is clear, continued to be available in the Yuan period along both the western and the eastern trunk routes.45 42DYZL, p. 177 n. 4; Lin Tianwei, Songdai xiangyao maoyi, table with list of imports, pp. 174 215. 43Ptak, "China and the Trade in Cloves", pp. 8-9; Th. M. This would seem to indicate that small quantities of nutmeg somehow reached China, perhaps by way of the Java Sea. 450n camphor, see, for example, Han Wai Toon (Han Huaizhun), "Notes on Bornean Camphor Imported to China", BMJ 6,1 (1985): 1-31 (this is an English version of Han's "Longnaoxiang kao", in Nanyang xuebao 2,1, no. 3 [1941]: 3-17); Robert Nicholl, "Brunei and Camphor", BMJ 4,3 (1979): 52-74; Roderich Ptak, "Camphor in East and Southeast Asian Trade, circa 1500: A Synthesis of Portuguese and Asian Sources", paper presented to the Vasco da Gama Conference in Melbourne and Perth, June 1997. For the places, see DYZL, pp. 44, 55, 79, 93, 102, 123, 141, 148, 173, 240. Sandalwood was the chief export of Timor. Wang Dayuan also mentions it as being used in Pulau Rondo and Hualuo (perhaps Veraval on the Indian west coast) but says nothing about the trade routes. He does state that "in the past" a Quanzhou merchant named Wu Zhai sent a trading vessel to Timor Island; though huge profits could be earned in these lands, many men died during the voyage. Wu Zhai cannot be identified but, as in the case of the Moluccas, this is clear evidence of Chinese vessels sailing to eastern Indonesia.46 There is no indication concerning the route which they took, yet it cannot be excluded that they sailed through the Sulu zone and then through Makassar Strait or the Flores Sea to reach Timor. Wang Dayuan's description of Timor is the first Chinese report on that island. In the Song period there are brief references to Timor and other islands in the Lesser Sunda chain and also to Chinese sandal wood imports from Java, Brunei, Srivijaya and Champa, but there is no description of Timor in these works. On one occasion, in 1017, Srivijaya is said to have sent almost 20,000 jin of sandalwood to China. This was an exceptionally large quantity. Most Song imports of this order were certainly channelled through the Java Sea first before they went to China ? in sharp contrast to the Yuan period, when trade was often via the direct route through the Sulu zone.47 The commodity flows outlined above underline the importance of the eastern route in the Yuan period. Of course, this eastern route was not exclusively operated by merchants from Quanzhou. Native vessels of the countries and ports in the Sulu zone and the Celebes were certainly involved in a multitude of local trading networks of which no details have been recorded in written sources. Philippine and Bornean ships, it is clear, also made their way into Quanzhou and other Chinese coastal cities. Yet, in the early fourteenth century, the Quanzhou Chinese were perhaps the chief carriers of trade between Fujian and the Sulu zone. Summary Foreign trade prospered under the Yuan. The eastern sea route ? from Quanzhou to the Sulu zone, northern Borneo, with a branch to the Celebes Sea and the Moluccas ? became an important link between insular Southeast Asia and China. Chinese junks proceeded along this route to the Sulu Islands and the Moluccas, and perhaps also to Timor. Ceramics from Fujian and other provinces were distributed in large numbers to the Philippines and northern Borneo. Spices, tortoise-shell, camphor and other commodities went in the other direction. Islamic elements certainly played an important part in these developments. Under the Song, trade mainly followed the western route connecting continental Southeast Asia and western Indonesia to Hainan and Guangzhou. Champa was an important entrep?t in this system. From there supplementary routes ran to Mindoro and northern Borneo. Both these routes converged in the Sulu zone. Commodities produced in eastern Indonesia and around the Sulu zone could thus be brought to China by way of Champa, 46Roderich Ptak, "Some References to Timor in Old Chinese Records", Ming Studies 17 (1983): and from Champa to Guangzhou. Direct traffic from the Philippines to Quanzhou was less frequent than in Yuan times. The two major Philippine places involved in trade to Guangzhou and Champa, as well as Quanzhou, were Butuan and Mindoro. Song ceramics, found in Butuan, underline the links of that port across the South China Sea. In Yuan times the horizontal trade axis from Mindoro to Champa was no longer important. Islamic merchants, previously involved in this link, were now looking to the eastern route. Political factors such as Mongol moves against Indochina and Java also made it more advantageous for seagoing merchants to shift their activities to the eastern connection. This shift increased the importance of the Sulu Islands and northern Borneo. At the same time, Butuan declined. Tanjongpura was probably seen as a "buffer" between the Sulu zone and Java's sphere of influence. Chinese trade along the eastern route, to the Sulu zone, the Celebes Sea and beyond, also strengthened the position of Quanzhou vis-?-vis that of Guangzhou. Yuan imports from eastern Indonesia included such items as Moluccan cloves. However, Quanzhou and the eastern route only remained strong till the outbreak of the Isfahan movement. The Nanhai zhi and the DYZL reflect the changes which had occurred after the Mongol takeover of power. The Sulu zone came to be known as the "Small Eastern Ocean", or as part of the "Eastern Ocean". Although the concept of an "Eastern Ocean" already existed in Song times, it was first elaborated under the Yuan and made to suit the new constellation of commercial power that had evolved in the meantime. After the Isfahan rebellion, the system of Chinese sea routes changed anew. The Hongwu emperor prohibited private trade ? to the continued disadvantage of Quanzhou. Official contacts between the early Ming and southern countries remained restricted to the western sea link. As a result, the eastern route declined. It was only moderately revived after 1400 when tribute missions from Luzon, the Sulu Islands, northern Borneo and other eastern places began arriving at the court of Yongle. Trade across the South China Sea, from the Philippines to Vietnam, is not recorded for this period. The abrupt end of the great expeditions led by Zheng He and other court eunuchs led to a shortage in supplies at the China end because private trade remained interdicted. But private Chinese traders did not obey the laws. They either traded with the Ry?ky? Islands or clandestinely sailed to Southeast Asia, and this included the Philippines and other places along the eastern route. In the mid-sixteenth century, illegal activities led to violence along the China coast. In 1567, when the ban on private trade was lifted, the eastern route began to flourish again. But, at the Fujian end, this trade no longer focused on Quanzhou. During the mid-14th century, it seems possible that Temasik became more unified.

That they did defend their city against armed invaders is confirmed by both Wang Dayuan and the Malay Annals. They must have had some sort of military organisation which was able to withstand attacks from much larger neighbours, notably Xien/Siam, and Java-based Majapahit.

Wang Dayuan’s Pancur can be identified with high probability as a reference to today’s Fort Canning Hill. Springs on hills were often thought to be sacred. The Hindu image of Mount Meru at the centre of the universe — where Indra, king of the gods, resided — is closely connected with Asian symbols of kingship.

Wang Dayuan, a Chinese trader and would-be member of the literati class, wrote a text entitled Dao yi zhi lue ( Description of the Barbarians of the Isles ; hereafter abbreviated as Barbarians of the Isles ), published in 1349. He was born around 1311 in Nanchang, Jiangxi Province, which became a prosperous port during the Song Dynasty.

According to Wang Dayuan, this is where ships returning to China from the Western Ocean (that is, India) formed a fleet for safety, and prepared for battle against the pirates in the Dragon’s Tooth Strait. According to the Portuguese, it was the Sea People who discovered the site of Melaka after the ruler was driven out of Singapore.

results.text: 103 Temasik to Singapura: Singapore in the 14th to 15th Centuries John Miksic Singapore was a city before it was even called by this name. Long before the settlement was revived by Stamford Raffles in 1819, the north bank of the Singapore River was linked to regional flows of people, culture, religious ideas, and trade. This chapter asks: who were the inhabitants of 14thto 15th-century “Singapore” (or Temasik, Banzu, or any of its various other names)? Did they think of themselves as Singaporeans or Malays or did they think of themselves as having other identities? Did these inhabitants imagine that they could make this island a centre of importance in the world they inhabited? Singapore appears in Malay, Chinese, Javanese, and Vietnamese records as a place of some significance. What sort of singularity, uniqueness, or comparative advantage, did the island and its inhabitants have? By trying to answer these questions, this chapter may provide a feel for what it was like to live on the island we now call Singapore in the period from the 14th to the early 17th centuries. Many people still assume that ancient Singapore belongs to the world of fable rather than history. 1 Enough archaeological evidence has been 05 SS21c.indd collected since 1984 to confirm the hypothesis that by 1330, Singapore was already a going concern. Hundreds of thousands of artefacts, local and foreign, especially pottery sherds, broken pieces of pottery unearthed from ancient urban contexts, leave no room for doubt that 500 years before Thomas Stamford Raffles made a pact with local Malay rulers, a forerunner to the hypermodern metropolis now occupying this island already existed. This new information allows us to reconsider ancient written records, and integrate Longyamen, Banzu, and Temasik into the history of Singapore. In the absence of any effusive documents, attempts to imagine how the people of Singapore actually thought of themselves, what emotional connection they felt to this piece of land, in a word their identities, must be speculative. How did inhabitants of “the-place-now-called-Singapore” of the 14th century perceive their place in the world? Would they have called themselves Singaporeans? It might be more prudent to leave these questions alone, since no definitive answer can ever be given, but the undeniable interest these subjects now raise can be cited as reasonable justification for describing a range of answers, and presenting reasons why some answers are more plausible than others. This chapter sets the stage by discussing places with comparable characteristics to Singapore, thus allowing us to form some conjectures regarding the probable composition of Singapore’s population in 1350 and its ethnic diversity. We can reconstruct with some degree of confidence a picture of how various groups came to Singapore, and how they perceived their relations with their fellow residents who came from different origins. Next, we can imagine how people here saw their place in an international context. They were certainly concerned about relations with Java, Sumatra, Vietnam, Siam, South Asia, and China. The conclusion of these deliberations is that some relationships and identities were surprisingly similar to contemporary concepts of Singaporeans as people with both local and global points of reference. The date of the inscription is unknown, but must date from the period before the region was converted to Islam in the early 15th century. The conclusion which can be drawn from this data is that Singapore was home to a literate population in the pre-Islamic period. This contrasts with the common perception that precolonial Singapore had been no more than a backwater, a primitive fishing village and haunt of sea rovers. Singapore continued to exist after its ruler, Iskandar Syah, was expelled in the late 14th century. This is recorded in the Malay Annals / Genealogy of Kings , and proven by archaeological remains found along the Singapore River at Empress Place, Old Parliament House, and Parliament House Complex. In the Malay Annals / Genealogy of Kings , when Melaka was founded, Singapura became the domain of the son of Sri Bija Diraja, perhaps as an inheritance from Sri Bija Diraja himself. Sri Bija Diraja was the Laksamana , the commander of the Sultanate’s maritime forces. 39 hero the Annals , Hang Tuah, held the same title. During the reign of Syah, Melaka’s most glorious period, Singapura was said to maintain 40 three-masted cruisers. 40 Singapura and its surrounding islands was the main naval base of Melaka, which had no seafaring population of its own. Singapore’s seafaring experts probably belonged to two groups. One would have been the more land-oriented people of Temasik (notably Banzu), who pursued a range of economic activities including fishing, trading, industry, and agriculture. Another important source of seafaring manpower would have been the people called orang laut (“sea people” in Malay), and Çelates (from the Malay word selat , “strait”) by the Portuguese. Both Portuguese and Malay records agree that when the Palembang ruler had moved to Singapore, one of his main sources of support had been a group of Sea People. According to the Portuguese, the Sea People who came with this ruler from Palembang (or perhaps Bangka) chose not to live in Singapore. Instead they stayed at Karimun. The Portuguese say they felt unwelcome in Singapore. The island of Karimun occupies a strategic position at the south end of the Straits of Melaka. It lies about 30 kilometres west of Singapore, and is visible from the latter from atop its hills and tall buildings. A rock face on the north side of Karimun bears a Sanskrit inscription carved in the eighth or ninth century, during Srivijaya’s golden age, indicating that the population there had some part to play in the kingdom. They may have watched over the shipping, compelling it to call at Srivijaya in order to pay tolls. Zhao Ruguo suggests that foreign ships may have paid toll there rather than diverting to Palembang. Chinese sailing directions of the Yuan and Ming Dynasties refer to Karimun as an important navigational landmark. According to Wang Dayuan, this is where ships returning to China from the Western Ocean (that is, India) formed a fleet for safety, and prepared for battle against the pirates in the Dragon’s Tooth Strait. According to the Portuguese, it was the Sea People who discovered the site of Melaka after the ruler was driven out of Singapore. When the Portuguese took Melaka, the laksamana was a descendant of these Sea People. Thus, Hang Tuah may have been a member of this group. After the fall of Melaka in 1511, the Malay capital returned to the Johor-Singapore-Riau area. The sea people there were divided into different suku (“tribes”, communities; small groups), usually speaking a Malay-related dialect, occupying a particular range of sea and islands, and carrying on special occupations. The Suku Mantang specialised in making swords and spears. Others were rowers, providing “transport of envoys and letters to rulers in foreign countries”, producers of agar-agar and sago, suppliers of water and wood, or of hunting dogs. 41 In the 16th and 17th centuries, European sources depict the sea people as the Malay sultans’ most loyal subjects. 17th-century Dutch sources say that the chief of the sea people of Singapore had the title Raja Negara Selat (king of the country [or town] of the Straits). 42 Their link to the Malay rulers was only severed in 1699, when the last sultan with a claim to be directly descended from Sri Tri Buana, the Malays’ first king and founder of Singapore in the Malay Annals / Genealogy of Kings , was assassinated. The sea people, having lost their focal point in the person of the Malay royal line, dissolved into fragmented and isolated groups, and many eventually adopted Malay identity. In 1515, the Portuguese said that the people who lived in Singapura were Çelates. 43 Supposedly the officers of Bendahara and Laksamana were hereditary among the Çelates in Melaka. By the time the British arrived in Singapore in 1819, several suku of sea people still lived here. The Singapore River belonged to the Suku Gelam, who also lived on Batam and other nearby islands. Munshi Abdullah mentioned that they worshipped a rock near the mouth of the Singapore River, which may have been the Singapore Stone. After the British arrived, they moved to the nearby Pulau Berani. By the early 1920s, they had assimilated to Malay culture. 44 The Suku Seletar lived on boats around mangrove swamps on the north coast of Singapore near the Seletar River mouth. The Biduanda-Kallang people who lived in the mangrove swamp at the Kallang River were decimated in a smallpox epidemic in 1848. 45 There were thus two groups who could lay claim to being natives of Singapore in 1330: the estuarine-dwellers around the Singapore River, and the piratical or raiding population around the Dragon’s Tooth Strait. They differed in many fundamental respects, probably including religion (as will be explained later). Each had its own rulers, and political and economic systems. The defensive fortification which may already have existed in Wang Dayuan’s time may have been meant at least in part to protect the estuarine dwellers from the other, although Wang only mentions an attack by the Siamese. During the mid-14th century, it seems possible that Temasik became more unified. Archaeological remains excavated on seven sites thus far studied in the ancient urban area around Fort Canning Hill indicate a population of unusual discernment and material wealth. Research in the islands of Riau also indicate that the people there, while still culturally distinct from those of Temasik, were linked with them in a commercial 05 SS21c.indd 120 8/30/10 network which made both sides rich. The 14th-century remains excavated from Singapore reveal relatively equal proportions of Chinese and local pottery. It is difficult to draw firm conclusions from this data. For comparison, ceramics at Kota Cina (northeast Sumatra) included 30 per cent Chinese ware in the 12th and 13th centuries. No Southeast Asian sites from the 14th century are as well documented as Singapore; thus we cannot draw any comparisons with contemporary trading ports. The increase in Chinese ware in 14th-century Singapore may be due to chronological factors (for example, declining prices of Chinese ceramics) rather than increasing wealth of the local population. In terms of quality of Chinese artefacts, however, some unusually rare items, found on Fort Canning Hill, strongly suggest that Singapore had special access to, and interest in, Chinese items. These include a Chinese bowl with compass directions written under the glaze. This is a unique object; no similar item has been reported even in China. Other finds consist of fragments of a pillow of white porcelain with the highly refined form of a Chinese theatre, an intricate artefact only a few examples of which are known from China, and the use of which was probably confined to the elite. Fragments of large white porcelain incense burners have also been found on Fort Canning (the “Forbidden Hill”). Another unique type of artefact consists of shards of elaborate glass vessels. Chemical analysis has shown that they were made in China; once again, no such artefacts have been reported from Chinese sites. 46 It is probable that they were made in a south Chinese port, possibly Quanzhou, where Arab tastes were well known, and Chinese glassmakers may have learnt new techniques from Arab craftsmen. Approximately 10,000 Chinese glass beads were also found on Fort Canning Hill, in comparison with a mere handful from the other six sites so far investigated. This data confirms the validity of the name Bukit Larangan (Forbidden Hill), by which Fort Canning was known in 1819. The story that the hill had once been a palace is almost certainly true; these unique items suggest a high degree of social differentiation between the elite on the hill and the commoners settled on the plain below. Fragments of gold, including a cache of gold jewellery found in 1928 on the hill, add further weight to this hypothesis, as does the report of John Crawfurd in 1822 that the eastern and northern slopes of the hill bore numerous ruins of buildings of good quality brick. Few brick fragments have so far been found in 14th-century strata on the hill, but the site of the modern Keramat Iskandar Syah (shrine for Iskandar Syah) almost certainly marks the former location of one of these buildings. 05 SS21c.indd 121 8/30/10 The Bukit Larangan site seems to have been abandoned by 1400, probably evidence of the evacuation of the local ruler to Melaka. The economy of 14th-century Temasik was based on trade and manufacturing. Wang Dayuan only mentions distilling of rice wine. Fort Canning has yielded traces of gold and glass working (recycling of broken Chinese shards to make bracelets). Copper, bronze, and iron working have been documented at the nearby Parliament House Complex and the Singapore Cricket Club sites. All these required the import of raw materials and their transformation in Singapore. This evidence for occupational specialisation is augmented by plentiful and widespread discoveries of coins, mainly Chinese but including a few Sri Lankan coins. Their distribution and quantity strongly suggest that they were used as the basic medium of exchange in the city. Thus, monetisation had proceeded to a significant extent, setting the society quite apart from any suggestion of a simple barter trade. Chinese artefacts thus provide abundant evidence for the importance of a commercial link with China. Other imported items came from Java, Thailand, Vietnam, and India. These are much less numerous, but this may be misleading, because their exports to Singapore may have been of perishable nature, including food and clothing. The Malay Annals / Genealogy of Kings does not mention Chinese trade, but does mention Singapore’s relations with India. For example, the second ruler of Singapore, Paduka Sri Pikrama Wira, was said to have married Princess Talai Puchudi of Kalinga, a kingdom on India’s east coast. 47 Were there Indians resident at Temasik, or were there at least strong links to India? The evidence is equivocal for another regional centre: Bandar Bapahat. Here, near the probable location of a 14th-century palace of a ruler named Adityawarman at Bukit Gombak, west Sumatra, a channel for water was hewn into rock. On one side was an inscription in a particular form of localised Sanskrit typical of the 14th century. On the other side of the channel, was an inscription in south Indian Grantha. This may or not signify that there was “an important south Indian component among the subjects of Adityawarman”. 48 Similarly, archaeological data does not permit us to conclude that there were Indian (or Sri Lankan) inhabitants in 14th-century Temasik. The discovery of imported south Asian (Indian or Sri Lankan) statuary in nearby Kota Cina from the 12th or 13th century, and the 11th-century Tamil inscription at Barus, however, indicate that south Asians would not have been strangers to Singapore’s shores. There is as yet no evidence that Hinduism existed as an organised religion in ancient 05 SS21c.indd 122 8/30/10 Singapore, but no Buddhist objects have yet been discovered either. This complete lack of clearly religious objects is surprising, given Crawfurd’s description of extensive brick ruins on Fort Canning Hill, which must have been religious sanctuaries. The mundane nature of all artefacts so far discovered suggests that the interests of 14th-century Singaporeans were mainly commercial in nature. Singapore’s economy was therefore quite well developed in the 14th century. Our data does not permit us to distinguish between different phases during this period; it is possible that Singapore’s prosperity and sophistication became more pronounced after Wang’s visits in the 1330s, when the settlement may have been only 30 years old. One way in which Singapore could have become more prosperous would have been through an expansion of its role as a local commercial hub. Evidence that this did occur comes in the form of numerous discoveries of 14th-century Chinese pottery in graves in the nearby islands of Riau. Chinese traders did not go to these islands; at least no records of such contact exist in Zhao Ruguo or Wang Dayuan (or in Ma Guan or other Ming writers either). The inescapable conclusion is that the people of Riau obtained their imported items in Singapore. Riau people had numerous commodities which were highly prized in China at the time. These included pearls, tortoise shell, coral, and a sausage-like marine creature called a sea cucumber. All these, being sea products, the sea nomads or orang laut were perfectly suited to provide. Thus, by the mid-14th century, the people of the Dragon’s Tooth Strait may have shifted the main weight of their activities from preying upon traders to becoming traders; not directly with the Chinese, but through Singapore. This kind of symbiotic relationship was typical of the relations between Malays and orang laut in later times. The discovery of many burials on the islands of Riau as far from Singapore as the Natuna Islands and the island of Midai, hundreds of kilometres away, indicates the scale of this commerce. Some form of economic exchange such as barter may have been involved; possibly the Sea Nomads of those islands delivered marine products to the Temasik rulers as a kind of tribute, in return for tokens of esteem in the form of Chinese wares and gold jewellery. At least one person was buried with a boat on the island of Midai. This type of burial custom is associated with local Southeast Asian beliefs dating to prehistoric times which focus on the ability of the ancestors to affect the living, for better and for worse. They had to be propitiated. This belief had long disappeared from the commonly A cucumbers, along with hornbill casques, were just some of the many forest and marine products exported fr o m the Straits of Melaka and islands of maritime Southeast Asia. In a way, they are one of the key forces behind the Straits and S outheast Asian in ansfor maritime trading kingdoms of the Straits of Melaka. No burials have ever been found in such sites as Kota Cina or anywhere on Singapore. This is due to the fact that the fundamental religion in these areas was Mahayana Buddhism. The elite in particular usually sought to become initiated into higher and higher orders of esoteric Buddhist ritual. Thus, no offerings were given to the dead, who according to Chinese accounts, were usually cremated and whose ashes were thrown into the sea or rivers. Thus, the two belief systems continued to exist side by side: the sea nomads perpetuating their non-Indic beliefs, the Temasik land dwellers following Buddhism which had been implanted firmly in South Sumatra by the beginning of the kingdom of Srivijaya in the seventh century. The two identities thus coexisted despite the regular communication and exchanges between them. This pattern continues today; on the island of Karimun, a population of sea nomads still lives near the ancient Srivijayan inscription. They call themselves orang akit , not orang malayu; they live mainly by fishing and their religion is not Muslim. They claim to be Buddhist, but possess neither statuary nor temples other than a rude hut on the edge of the village. That such an identity still persists today is testimony to the natural and anthropological dynamics which favour the perpetuation of numerous alternative ethnicities in the Singapore region. 14th-century Singapore maintained diplomatic relations with the Mongols in the early period, and with Vietnam, according to Vietnamese sources. Javanese sources claim that Temasik was part of the empire of Majapahit by 1365. 49 The Pararaton ( Book of Kings ), in a famous episode, quotes the prime minister of Majapahit, Gajah Mada, as taking an oath to conquer a list of countries. These are listed in geographical order; Temasik Borneo. Portuguese maps and finds of the late Ming Dynasty porcelain show that Singapore continued to be a trading port until the early 17th century. Then, the settlement at the Singapore River estuary seems to have been abandoned, perhaps as the result of an attack by the Acehnese. For the next two centuries, probably only a few small bands of sea people held out on Singapore’s fringes. Place names such as Tanah Merah, Sungai Bedok, and Tanjong Rhu, found on Eredia’s map of Singapore, still exist today. Archaeological research along Singapore’s east coast may yet reveal evidence that there were villages in that area, even though the old urban area around the Singapore River had been abandoned. 51 The Forbidden recycling to make bangles, and gold working, were probably conducted in the same area; in other words, the site may have been a palace craftsmen’s zone. In the 15th century, after the founding of Melaka, Portuguese sources record that Singapore’s population gradually moved north to the new port. results.text: 11 The Archaeology of Singapore John N. Miksic The fi rst systematic archaeological excavation in Singapore was conducted in 1984 (Miksic 2013 ), but explorations into the material remains of the country have a much longer history. The English East India Company of fi cer Sir Thomas Stamford Raf fl es chose the island of Singapore as a base for operations in 1819 due to its location at the south end of the Straits of Melaka, where major navigational routes between India and China, and Indonesia converge. He was also attracted by Singapore ’ s image in local history as the fi rst great Malay trading port. Upon landing there, he discovered abundant remains of an ancient settlement. John Crawfurd, another EIC of fi cial and fellow antiquarian, described an earthen rampart a kilometer long, ruins of brick buildings, Chinese pottery and coins dating from the ninth through thirteenth centuries, and a large boulder with an inscription in an indecipherable script. These discoveries appeared to con fi rm Malay tradition, but the development of archaeology as a scholarly fi eld of research never caught on in the colony, despite chance discoveries of stone tools in the 1890s and of ancient gold jewelry in the 1920s. Even after independence in 1963, neither governmental nor academic institutions paid any attention to the subject. In 1984 curators of the National Museum of Singapore and an of fi cial from another branch of the government managed to obtain a grant from the Royal Dutch Shell Petroleum Company to sponsor a 10-day excavation. The site chosen for research had been known as Fort Canning since an artillery fort was built there in 1858 (Fig. 11.1 ). The existence of a keramat or heterodox Muslim shrine popularly regarded as the last resting place of Iskandar Shah, the last of fi ve ancient kings of Singapore, and the legend that the hill had been the site of an ancient palace which was current when the British arrived in 1819, were two factors that led to the site ’ s selection. A third factor was that the hill had been turned into a park after independence, and several potential sites for excavation on the northeast side of the hill near the Keramat were available, though the summit of the hill itself had long ago been completely disturbed, fi rst by construction of the fort, then by demolition of the fort in 1928 to construct a service reservoir there. The excavation succeeded in fi nding undisturbed soil strata datable to the fourteenth century by Chinese stoneware and porcelain associated with local earthenware. The site has been excavated periodically ever since. At the present excavations are limited to rescue projects when a construction project, such as a ramp for wheelchair access to the hill, is imminent. Excavations conducted in other parts of the central business district since 1990 have de fi ned the boundaries of an area covering 85 ha, J.N. Miksic The ancient settlement is bounded by the site of the old rampart (which was leveled in the 1820s) on the northeast, Fort Canning Hill on the northwest, the Singapore River on the southwest, and an area of reclaimed land which marks an area which was a white sandy beach in the fourteenth century. Within this zone, eight sites have been examined and large quantities of artifacts have been recovered. The most common items are Chinese porcelains and stonewares of the late Yuan Dynasty (1260 – 1367). This is an interesting period during which early overseas Chinese settlements began to form, commerce expanded, Islam began to gain footholds in Southeast Asia, and two large empires controlled much of the region: Ayutthaya (founded 1351) on the mainland, and Majapahit (founded 1294) in Indonesia. There is evidence that Singapore was one of the fi rst sites to support a sizeable population of Chinese who resided in the region for long periods, and that it was ruled by Malays who paid tribute both to Majapahit and Ayutthaya. Chinese historical sources begin to mention Longya men ( “ Dragon ’ s Tooth Strait ” ) and Danmaxi (Temasek, an old Malay name for Singapore and its environs) in the 1320s, when diplomatic and trading missions were exchanged between the governments. Danmaxi is described in detail by Wang Dayuan, a Chinese merchant who visited it several times in the 1330s. The Malay Annals , the oldest existing recension of which is dated 1612, describes Singapore as the fi rst great Malay trading port, but this is misleading. Major ports in the Singapore area had been founded on Sumatra by the seventh century at the latest. Fourteenth-century Singapore must have been a place of some signi fi cance, since it managed to stamp its image fi rmly on the Malay consciousness, but it was the heir of a long period of commercial and artistic development in the region. Singapore ’ s main claim to archaeological attention is its status as an early port with a large Chinese presence. It represents a class of “ ports of trade ” in the term popularized by Karl Polanyi (Miksic 2004 ; Polanyi et al. 1957 ), or the heterogenetic city (Miksic 2000 ). The historian Edward Fox identi fi ed a similar type of port city, which evolved along the margins of the continental kingdoms of premodern Europe (Fox 1971 ). Many such heterogenetic cities must have existed in Asia, but their archaeological remains are much less impressive than those of the inland empires. As a result, they have been largely neglected by archaeologists. It is likely that premodern Southeast Asian trading ports such as Singapore accommodated sizeable populations with cosmopolitan and hybrid social structures, where complex and dynamic economic institutions evolved; these ports were the conduits through which new religions and economic practices penetrated the orthogenetic societies of the hinterland. The dense population of fourteenth-century Temasek (ancient Singapore) used bronze Chinese coins (some Sri Lankan coins have also been found) in everyday commerce, whereas coinage was not used in the great mainland empires of Angkor, Ayutthaya, or Bagan. The capitals of the mainland empires were mainly devoted to large temples and palaces inhabited largely by priests, bureaucrats, and their servants; industries must have been dispersed over a broad swath of the surrounding countryside. In Temasek, evidence of the working of metal (iron, copper, gold) and glass recycling is found almost everywhere, even on the middle slope of Fort Canning Hill on top of which the ancient rulers probably lived. The Parliament House Complex site revealed a probable copper-working industry (Zaini 1997 ). Imported pottery makes up more than half of the total ceramic assemblage of the site. Some pottery was made locally, but it seems that imported porcelain and stoneware were so abundant and cheap that they relegated local earthenwares to restricted functions, such as cooking pots. Evidence from shipwrecks in Southeast Asia suggests that Chinese cast iron frying pans, or wok s, were exported to the region in such huge quantities that they were shipped as ballast. These characteristics contrast strongly with the mainland empires, where local industries provided most of the items used in daily life. Locally made artifacts found in Singapore consist mainly of paddle-marked earthenware pottery similar in style to those found from southern Thailand through the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra to 11 The Archaeology of Singapore 121 western Borneo. The fi rst British observers to the city-state noted the existence of suitable clay for pottery-making at Bras Basah, just outside the rampart which formed the settlement ’ s northeastern boundary. Copper was imported, probably from Sumatra, to make fi sh hooks and wire. Elaborately worked gold jewelry, found by accident on Fort Canning, is similar to the design carved on a stone statue found in west Sumatra, dated to the fourteenth century. It may have been made locally; gold crucibles and scraps of gold foil have been found on Fort Canning. Wang Dayuan in the 1330s noted that people of Temasek also made a type of wine. Chinese porcelain found in Singapore contains a large proportion of early cobalt blue decorated wares, and some unique items such as a compass bowl (Fig. 11.2 ). A signi fi cant quantity of Chinese glassware has also been found on Fort Canning; no comparable examples have yet been reported from China. Temasek was probably an important collecting point for sea products from the Riau Archipelago south of Singapore, which is now part of Indonesia. Exploration of surface remains and contacts with antique sellers in markets in the Pulau Tujuh and Bintan regions of Riau have con fi rmed that local inhabitants in the fourteenth century buried their dead with grave goods, including Chinese porcelain, Thai ceramics (Low Mei Gek 2002 ), gold jewelry, glass and stone beads and, in at least one case, a dugout canoe. The inhabitants of Singapore in contrast do not seem to have buried their dead, suggesting that they probably disposed of them by cremation, a Buddhist burial custom. Buddhism was probably the prevailing religion in Temasek, as it was in Sumatra and the Malay peninsula at the same time. Warfare seems to have been a constant threat to Temasek. Wang Dayuan mentions a siege by a fl eet from Xian , a cognate of “ Shan/Siam, ” probably denoting a group from the southern Chao Phraya valley in modern Thailand. The Malay Annals mentions two attacks from Majapahit, and Temasek is listed as a Javanese vassal in a 1365 Javanese source. We do not know when Temasek ’ s name was changed to Singapore. This may have happened in the late fourteenth or early fi fteenth century. In the late sixteenth century the waters off Singapore ’ s shores were the scene of frequent con fl ict between the Malays, Acehnese, Dutch, and Portuguese. Late Ming Dynasty porcelain found along the bank of the Singapore River and at the Kallang basin con fi rms Portuguese reports that Singapore ’ s harbor still hosted international traders. In the early seventeenth century the port seems to have been abandoned amid the strife for control over the trade through the Singapore Strait.
